abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency National Solidarity
            Project (NSP) constitutes the backbone of the
            Government's National Solidarity Program (NSP), co
            financed by several donors through the Bank managed
            Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund. This additional
            financing would provide funds needed to scale-up activities
            under a successful emergency program in the social sector
            that has exceeded the original implementation (including
            disbursement) expectations. The funds to be added through
            this additional grant were not available under IDA 13 in
            June 2005. The scaled up activities are expected to be
            implemented by the original closing date, and are within the
            original project objectives, subject to the same
            implementation arrangements. The additional financing will
            require an amendment to the Development Grant Agreement to
            increase the amount of Block Grants category by US$24.4
            million, Consultants Services, facilitation and training by
            US$15.0 million, Goods by 0.5 million, and Incremental
            Operating Costs by 0.1 million. It is expected the
            additional financing will further community-led
            reconstruction and development of rural infrastructure.
            Approximately 70 percent of program funds return to local
            labor, and virtually all of the benefits from the physical
            works accrue to primary producers. Sub-project choices by
            villagers include physical infrastructure, direct asset
            transfers (e.g. tools and equipment for income generation
            activities) for vulnerable women and disabled people, and
            the use of block grants for income generation activities.
            While premature to estimate economic and financial benefits
            in the current Afghanistan disrupted environment, NSP data
            are being collected however, to enable an estimate of
            expected returns on individual subproject investments. This
            additional grant faces the same implementation risks as the
            overall program, and specific risk and mitigation measures
            that currently apply to NSP remain pertinent.
